resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The distinct roles of each cat is shown by the duality of their meals : the pet cat is eating a piece of meat provided by humans and put on a plate, which highlights its indoor lifestyle.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The distinct roles of each cat is shown by the duality of their meals : the "chat de gouttière" is hunting a mouse, which highlights its role and its outdoor lifestyle.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: A "mice destruction" contest is advertise in big letters on the poster, which means that it is regarded as one of the main event of the cat show. Similarly to dog breeding, cat breeding mostly appealed to the upper classes, so it could be a way to attract a more popular audience, for which purebred cats breeding may not be important, but for which rodent control definitly is. Rodent were such a problem at the turn of the XIXth century that the municipality of Paris even organized a rat destruction contest in 1901, involving this time pest control experts, not cats (see <a href="https://www.retronews.fr/sante/echo-de-presse/2018/08/08/1901-la-chasse-aux-rats-dans-paris" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lamure Priscile, "1901 : La chasse aux rats dans Paris", Retronews, 2018)
resource.chars: A "mice destruction" contest is advertise in big letters on the poster, which means that it is regarded as one of the main event of the cat show. Similarly to dog breeding, cat breeding mostly appealed to the upper classes, so it could be a way to attract a more popular audience, for which purebred cats breeding may not be important, but for which rodent control definitly is. Rodent were such a problem at the turn of the XIXth century that the municipality of Paris even organized a rat destruction contest in 1901, involving this time pest control experts, not cats (see Lamure Priscile, "1901 : La chasse aux rats dans Paris", Retronews, 2018)

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: As opposed to the other cat, this feline represents the traditionnal and utilitarian role of cats, that is to say rodent control.
resource.chars: As opposed to the other cat, this feline represents the traditionnal and utilitarian role of cats, that is to say rodent control.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: As opposed to the other cat, this individual represents a purebred cat or, at least, a pet cat. This aspect is shown by the ribbon around the cat's neck, along with its semi-long fur and quieter attitude.
resource.chars: As opposed to the other cat, this individual represents a purebred cat or, at least, a pet cat. This aspect is shown by the ribbon around the cat's neck, along with its semi-long fur and quieter attitude.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The visual association of the gutter and the cat next to it may be a reference to the french phrase "chat de gouttière" ("gouttière" being the french word for "gutter"). A "chat de gouttière" is a cat that does not belong to a particular cat breed. This evocation reinforces the contrast between the two cats and their dedicated roles, particularly because the cat on the right, with its striped fur, conventionally looks like a "chat de gouttière", and because these cats are seen as the best hunters (see <a href="http://thesaurus.altervista.org/dict/fr/souris" target="_blank" rel="noopener">« Souris », in the Grande encyclopédie illustrée d’Économie domestique et rurale, by Jules Trousset, Paris : chez Fayard frères, s.d. (vers 1875), p. 2310)
resource.chars: The visual association of the gutter and the cat next to it may be a reference to the french phrase "chat de gouttière" ("gouttière" being the french word for "gutter"). A "chat de gouttière" is a cat that does not belong to a particular cat breed. This evocation reinforces the contrast between the two cats and their dedicated roles, particularly because the cat on the right, with its striped fur, conventionally looks like a "chat de gouttière", and because these cats are seen as the best hunters (see « Souris », in the Grande encyclopédie illustrée d’Économie domestique et rurale, by Jules Trousset, Paris : chez Fayard frères, s.d. (vers 1875), p. 2310)
